fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A sieve is a subfunctor of a contravariant hom-functor. Explicitly, a sieve S on x\in C consists of a collection of maps with codomain x that is closed under precomposition, i.e. if z\xrightarrow {f}x\in S and z'\xrightarrow {g} z is any map, then fh\in S.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Sheaves in geometry and logic
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: @book{maclane-moerdijk-1994, title = {Sheaves in Geometry and Logic: A First Introduction to Topos Theory}, author = {MacLane, S. and Moerdijk, I.}, isbn = {9781461209270}, doi = {10.1007/978-1-4612-0927-0} lccn = {91033709}, series = {Universitext}, url = {https://books.google.com/books?id=LZWLBAAAQBAJ}, year = {1994}, publisher = {Springer New York}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We dedicate this book to the memory of J. Frank Adams. His clear insights have inspired many mathematicians, including both of us. In January 1989, when the first draft of our book had been completed, we heard the sad news of his untimely death. This has cast a shadow on our subsequent work. Our views of topos theory, as presented here, have been shaped by continued study, by conferences, and by many personal contacts with friends and colleagues-including especially O. Bruno, P. Freyd, J.M.E. Hyland, P.T. Johnstone, A. Joyal, A. Kock, F.W. Lawvere, G.E. Reyes, R Solovay, R Swan, RW. Thomason, M. Tierney, and G.C. Wraith. Our presentation combines ideas and results from these people and from many others, but we have not endeavored to specify the various original sources. Moreover, a number of people have assisted in our work by pro viding helpful comments on portions of the manuscript. In this respect, we extend our hearty thanks in particular to P. Corazza, K. Edwards, J. Greenlees, G. Janelidze, G. Lewis, and S. Schanuel.
Let C be a category so that any cospan has a cocone (i.e., C satisfies the right Ore condition). Then the atomic topology on C is the Grothendieck topology such that all nonempty sieves are covering.

Let P be a presheaf and S a sieve on x. Regarding S as a subfunctor of C(-, x), a matching family of P for S is just a natural transformation S\to P. Explicitly, a matching family assigns, to each y\xrightarrow {f} x in S, an element p_f\in P. This data must be compatible with restriction via P, in that p_f|_g = p_{fg} for all z\xrightarrow {g} y.
The maximal sieve on an object x is the sieve consisting of all arrows with codomain x; equivalently, the sieve associated to the contravariant hom-functor.
The trivial topology on a category C is the Grothendieck topology where the only covering sieve is the maximal sieve.
The topology generated by K is the Grothendieck topology wherein a sieve S covers an object x if and only if T\subseteq S for some T\in K(x).

Equivalently, say that a sieve S covers a map y\xrightarrow {f} x if the
pullback f^*S covers y. Then the axioms state: 
if f\in  S, then S covers f;
  
if S covers f, then it covers fg for any g where the
  composition makes sense;
  
if S covers f and T covers each g\in  S, then T covers
  f.
A category equipped with a Grothendieck topology is called a site.
In the backwards direction, if J satisfies the map axioms, then letting f = 1_x shows that it satisfies the object axioms.
In the forwards direction, let J satisfy the object axioms. Then:

fr:ul.fr:li: For any sieve S on x and any f\in S, f^*S covers the domain of f by the stability axiom, so S covers f.
If S covers f, then f^*S covers the domain of f, so that by stability g^*f^*S covers the domain of g.

If S covers y\xrightarrow {f} x and T covers each g\in S, then f^*S covers the y, while for each g\in S, g^*T covers the domain of g. Now by transitivity, T covers x, so that by stability, T covers f.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let S be a sieve on x\in C and y\xrightarrow {f} x any map. Then the pullback sieve f^*S consists of those z\xrightarrow {g} y in C such that z\xrightarrow {g}y\xrightarrow {f} x\in S.

Let \hat {C} be a presheaf category. Let C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {\Omega } Set be the sieve functor, which sends an object x to the set of sieves on x, and a map y\xrightarrow {f}x to its action on sieves by restriction: (\Omega f)(S) = \{g: fg\in S\}. Let *\xhookrightarrow {\top } \Omega (where * is the constant functor at the singleton) identify for each x\in C the maximal sieve. Then \top is a subobject classifier in \hat {C}.

Let Q\hookrightarrow P be a subobject in \hat {C}. We need to define the classifying natural transformation P\xrightarrow {\chi _Q}\Omega ; we work in components. At an object x\in C, this map must send an element p\in Px to a sieve on x; we choose the sieve (\chi _Q)_x(p) = \{z\xrightarrow {f} x\in C: p|_f \in Qz\}. In other words, this sieve consists of those maps which restrict p to an element of Q.

Next, to show that it is a pullback, it suffices to show that it is a pullback at each x\in C, and by the construction of limits in Set, it suffices to show that (\chi _Q)_x(p) is the maximal sieve if and only if p\in Qx. The backwards direction is already done; conversely, if it is the maximal sieve, then we obtain the result by observing that 1_x\in (\chi _Q)_x(p) and applying the definition of \chi _Q.

Finally, to show uniqueness, suppose that we have another natural transformation P\xrightarrow {\theta } \Omega . By the above argument, for the square to be a pullback, we must have that \theta _x(p) is the maximal sieve if and only if p\in Qx. Now further, given z\xrightarrow {f} x and applying the same fact at z, we must have that p|_f\in Qz if and only if \theta _z(p|_f) is the maximal sieve. By naturality of \theta at a map f, we have that \theta _z(p|_f) = \Omega f(\theta _x(p)), which by definition of \Omega is the maximal sieve if and only if f\in \theta _x(p). As a consequence, if the square is a pullback, we must have that f\in \theta _x(p) if and only if p|_f\in Qz, yielding exactly the definition of \chi _Q above.

A subfunctor of a [functor] C\xrightarrow {F} D is merely a subobject in the functor category D^C; this is computed pointwise, so that a subfunctor consists of a functor C\xrightarrow {G} D such that Gc\hookrightarrow Fc for each c\in C, naturally in C.
The disjoint union is the coproduct in Set. Explicitly, the disjoint union of sets A and B is A \sqcup B = \{(a, 0) \mid a \in A\} \cup \{(b, 1) \mid b \in B\}, where \cup denotes the union.

Let c be an object in a category C. The contravariant hom-functor C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {C(-, c)} Set takes an object x to the hom-set C(x, c) and a morphism x\xrightarrow {f} y to its action f^* by pre-composition:
This functor is also called the presheaf represented by c, and is written yc, y^c or h^c, the former two in reference to the Yoneda embedding.
